author: {'steamid': '76561198107778846', 'num_games_owned': 1172, 'num_reviews': 221, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1443337224}
review:
★看我的阿姆斯特朗回旋加速喷气式阿姆斯特朗炮~
★这游戏可搞基很不错。
★剧情刚开始我认为就是A去找B，A给了B一把阿姆斯特朗炮去拯救A说完A就被一个看似螃蟹的东西吞了，然后B就莫名其妙的去拯救A，救了后又回到原来的地方。C出现后面又跟着一个看似螃蟹的怪物C把B扔到了怪物嘴里（233）。没时间解释了快来救我阿姆斯特朗炮给你。
★可惜只支持本地合作并不能和其他玩家一起联机玩。
★游戏还有创意工坊可以订阅其他的地图。
★此游戏已经入过包，原本觉得只是喜+1的其实还是值得一玩的，可以和身边的朋友搞基。

author: {'steamid': '76561198032594664', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1442183935}
review:
[h1]Prefazione[/h1]
No time to explain è il primo titolo pubblicato da tinyBuild, a seguito di una campagna di successo su kickstarter che è riuscita a spingere il titolo sul greenlight di steam, fino a raggiungere il pubblico comune.

[h1]Recensione[/h1]
Il gioco si presenta fin da subito per ciò che è, [b]un'avventura a piattaforme infame[/b], che si rifà allo stile ormai consolidato da Super meat boy, aggiungendo però una nota ilare alla trama, che ci accompagnerà per tutta la durata della storia.

"Sono te stesso dal futuro, e non c'è tempo per spiegare!"
 Questa è la frase che racchiude e spiega appieno il gioco nella sua totalità: [b]la trama è molto semplice[/b] e servirà solo a dare un senso a livelli che sono caratterizzati da una struttura che richiederà spesso diversi tentativi per superarla, ma sempre seguendo un [b]gameplay frenetico[/b] che si baserà principalmente sulla [b]prontezza dei riflessi e sulle abilità di precisione del giocatore[/b]. Allo stesso modo gli scontri con i boss seguiranno formule semplici e la più grande difficoltà starà nello schivare i loro attacchi e cercare di non distrarsi mentre li si sta colpendo.

Il gameplay risulta essere la formula vincente e innovativa del titolo, ma allo stesso tempo, anche il suo più grande difetto. Controllare il fucile jetpack o le altre abilità dei personaggi richiederà troppa precisione, per superare delle difficoltà che sono di per se semplici. Finendo il gioco dopo una [b]quantità scarsa di ore[/b], infatti, ci si renderà conto di non averlo ancora padroneggiato a dovere, sperando in altre serie di livelli che purtroppo (o per fortuna), si potranno trovare solo nella comunità sviluppata grazie all'editor.

L'unico motivo per rigiocare il titolo sarà forse per completare gli achievements, i quali chiederanno di superare determinati livelli in tempi record, o di collezionare tutti i cappelli del gioco. I [b]cappelli collezionabili[/b] sono a mio parere la giusta idea realizzata come si deve, la maggior parte non è difficile da trovare ne da raggiungere, mentre altre volte bisognerà sviscerare per bene un intero livello. In ogni caso raccoglierli darà sempre una buona soddisfazione, seppur limitata al solo fattore estetico.

L'aspetto tecnico del gioco è molto semplice, [b]disegni e animazioni sono molto basilari[/b], e purtroppo alcune volte si farà anche fatica a capire in che posto ci si trovi o che oggetti si stanno guardando. Pessima l'idea di non inserire tra le opzioni un cambio di risoluzione. La colonna sonora del titolo è giusta e incalzante, accompagnando bene il giocatore. Nota di merito va al doppiatore di tutti i personaggi, che ha interpretato bene i suoi diversi compiti.

Nel complesso No Time To Explain si presenta come un [b]titolo simpatico[/b], che non vuole puntare in alto ma non si accontenta neanche di essere l'ultima ruota del carro che esce quotidianamente dal greenlight. Credo che preso in offerta possa fare la sua bella figura nella libreria di ogni giocatore.

Voto 6/10

*Giocato con mouse e tastiera, fullscreen a risoluzione 1280x720

author: {'steamid': '76561198102928828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1668928884}
review:
I got this game as part of a Humble Bundle, but had never heard of it before, and decided to try it.  I've beaten it twice and had so much fun that I would consider paying full price to buy it for a friend.

Even if nothing ever changes in this game, it already sits among my favourites.  If a sequel comes out and has the same adorable and hilarious style, the same hyperactive pacing and varied gameplay, and mind-bending plot, I would likely buy it at full price rather than wait for a price drop.  Seriously, this game is awesome.  Some of the levels can be frustratingly challenging, but it's only occasional and it adds to the charm.

My second time beating this was in 2-Player mode and we had a blast!  It had issues though:
- Game could benefit from a LEGO-game style adaptive split-screen (currently no zoom-out or split screen)
- Beams still cancel each other out even if the end boss is between the two players.

Other things I'd love to see in this game are:
- for it to have alternate button images for PS3/PS4 controllers.
- There's a bug I'd like to see fixed.  If you do not select Keyboard/Mouse as your control scheme (or sometimes if you used a gamepad and switched to mouse), I find the game doesn't automatically take precedence over the mouse.  So if you're using a game pad and click a mouse button, the game pauses and you go to your Desktop.  That's hard for me, because my PS4 trackpad is mapped as a mouse.  Thank goodness the game pauses!!  That's thinking ahead! <3

author: {'steamid': '76561197981867244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 219, 'last_played': 1442384576}
review:
A nice, fast placed 'hard platformer' comedy with a lot of psychological elements. The game is constantly trying to trick and troll you by subte means. It's very short, about three hours long (also includes a map editor for user made screens, but I'm not too fond of that stuff for most games). It plays rather much like a flash game, with the elements of complexity revolving around left-clicking and things like direction and moment.

There's a fair ammount of variety to the game mechanics. There are decent boss fights which tend to range from too long to too easy, but still manage to be enjoyable and use the game mechanics well.

There's a rather lengthy reference to the 'are video games art' debate, which I think is outdated to the point where only people who play nothing but Madden and people who are so liberal they think Burney Sanders is a fascist would bother arguing about. Anyway, those levels are very easy and aren't really funny, even though it constitutes about 80% of the game's unspoken dialogue. It slows down gameplay, and just annoyed and distracted me. 

Otherwise, the spoken dialogue is funny, but there's not a whole lot of it. No Time to Explain, in general, is very creative, but they could have done a lot more with the open-ended concept. The level editor leaves a lot to be desired, with no way to design full level campaign, the editor can only make a single screen. There doesn't seem to be a way to add any of the game's various 'suit powerups' in the editor.

For a short game, I'd say it's worth a playthrough, and is somewhat iconic of the cheap indie spectrum. It could have done a lot more, and it's pretty flash-game like. Still, definently a step ahead of even the best flash games. That said, for games this short I generally want more of a story, something with more context than a platformer with about 8 worlds and 25 levels.

I would not recommend it at the silly price of $15. Not for a 3 hour platformer with an editor that's an afterthought.

author: {'steamid': '76561198174901462', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3165, 'last_played': 1443224080}
review:
Awesome. A puzzle platformer with great mechanics. It makes sure to introduce a new way of playing at the right moments to keep you interested.

pros: 
-Great gameplay
-Decent story
-Funny
-Has secrets
-Has cosmetics

cons: 
-very short. Only lasted me about a week.
-Majority is skill based. You can only be strategic and puzzle-solving to a certain extent. Some levels get EXTREMELY FRUSTRATING!!! Especially for achievements and hats.
-singleplayer platformer. Great for casual... But to be competitive or have a ton of experience with puzzle games... It's somewhat dull.

Overall: 7.8/10. Comperable to braid... but only on certain parts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017271295', 'num_games_owned': 1087, 'num_reviews': 483, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1442179669}
review:
No Time To Explain fait un peu tout à l'arrache et l'assume à fond. C'est très con, certes, mais on n'a pas le temps de s'ennuyer.

La grosse originalité vient du fait que l'on se déplace et progresse en tirant avec son arme (façon jetpack). Une fois le jeu lancé, on est embarqué dans une succession de niveaux qui n'ont pas vraiment de sens mais qui sont prétextes à toute sortes d'idées de gameplay souvent très fun à jouer. On est vraiment dans l'esprit d'un Super Meat Boy, en moins exigeant et plus ramassé sur la durée. 

Si on adhère au délire globale et aux plateformers à tendance prise de tête, c'est de la bonne.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003718991', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1442314069}

author: {'steamid': '76561198031725194', 'num_games_owned': 1271, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1442149794}
review:
Great indie game! Gave me a similar vibe to some of McMillen's game, mechanically.

It's a neat idea that's unique and well explored! It a solid game! Although the main mechanic is using your laser to gain momentum and attack, it also adds different environmental mechanics, and sometimes switching the laser with something else (a bomb, a "rubber-band" like thing, etc.)

The levels are well designed, with cool, completely different boss-fights.

The audio-visual aspect didn't strike as all that impressive, but it serves the game well, being simple and clean.

I don't have much more to say. The story is balls to the wall crazy. I have no clue about what exactly happened, but I like it!

There are also some gimmicky levels that are pretty funny. Definitely recommend it.

review:
1Line Review:

What: NO TIME TO EXPLAIN is jump and run in the vein of SUPER MEAT BOY originally made in flash; this remastered version is the same game but entirely built in Unity.

And...

How: Using your blaster to get through the levels while enjoying a story with a great humor is a blast. (no pun intended)

Finally...

Who: Everybody who likes games that are similar to SUPER MEAT BOY and has nothing against a high difficulty-level will enjoy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017868496', 'num_games_owned': 968, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1474722161}

author: {'steamid': '76561197969730757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1541524479}
review:
After playing for merely half an hour, I can unsafely say: I love this game!
The music totally rocks and gives you that moving-forward,nothing-will-stop-me energy, custom heads that you collect as secret items add to this personal-conquest feeling, stuff is generally over-the-top, as it should be! If you don't mind the (occasional) difficulty of Super Meat Boy, consider this like SMB, but fun, heheh. It also has SMB's very wise design feature of instant respawn that keeps frustration a pathetic wannabe-obstacle.

This game kicks purchass!

Technically the game could use some improvements (menu options and usability, launch and load times!), but they seem to be in the making, and once I started playing the game, I had forgotten about those grievances in 10 seconds flat.
You need to be aware though that one level consists of a chain of little maps, so if you go to level selection, your progress is void. One level always ends with a boss, and that you need to finish in one go.

This game is a bragain.

A propos ... On a personal note, it's funny how the most buyworthy games tend to approach for a bargain. It's just out (in remastered version), and in a Humble Bundle on tier 1.
I woke up today to 18.8°C (again). Saw the bundle, checked the game here: 88% positive reviews. Bought it. Product key contained an 88. Installed it. Install size 1188 MB.
What does all this mean? ... No time to explain! Sometimes you just gotta go with the flow. (-8 8-)


Here's me after half an hour, after having defeated two bosses that are too aweplenty to talk about:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=516342757
( No time for taking screenshots during action. ;-) )

author: {'steamid': '76561198129453918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1438273758}
review:
"No Time To Explain" is in my experience a fun game that was enjoyable for as long as it took me to complete the story. That being said, I wouldn't recommend the game as it probably took me under an hour to complete the story. This 2D platformer is more humerous than it is difficult.

+ The plot is interesting and amusing.
+ The animations are fine.
+ The voice acting is decent.
+ The target audience will find this game funny.
+ Has a basic map editor which encourages further gameplay

- On start up you are always greeted with loud screaming despite changing the ingame sound settings.
- The story isn't very long.
- The game has very little replayability other than a goal to collect hats.
- The menu isn't convenient. I feel like it should be available at any given time but it isn't.
- The game doesn't have a community as far as I'm aware. (Probably an issue with marketing rather than the game.)
   - The map editor is a cluster of garbage maps and a lot of spam as a result of the lack of a community.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156984686', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1461979418}

author: {'steamid': '76561198069702908', 'num_games_owned': 408, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1686622636}
review: The original was a laggy piece of crap, with the game being unplayable in late world two. It was more of a proof of concept than anything. Meanwhile this remastered version allows people to finally play the game for what it's worth, with over-the-top humor everywhere. Original: 3/10, Remastered: 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015070459', 'num_games_owned': 811, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1440819675}
review:
Its like Super Meat Boy in that its a cutsie indie super-hard platformer, but without the tight controls that made trial and error stress-free. Often times you know what you need to do, but because the game is, by design, hard to control, its just dying over and over to perform the task. Hard-to-control games can be fun; Surgeon Simulator and Octodad are both examples of that. But those games instead always make sure that you're making progress. You can be careful and even mess up, but you can slowly make progress. You can slowly get a better idea of how to play those games.

No Time To Explain does not do that. No Time To Explain is not that. You will die a lot, not because you made mistakes, but because its designed to do that. While there are plenty of checkpoiints through the short levels to make sure you don't have to retry the crazy difficult maneuvers a second time, you don't ever realy learn how to control it better. The checkpoint system is merely a mercy call. 

Maybe this game is better for short spurts. A game to slowly chip away at. Its fun, sure, but its not worthy of great admiration. Get it on sale and kill time with it, but I can't imagine it'll be on anyone's favorites list.

author: {'steamid': '76561198175259313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1525975657}
review: je recommande ce jeu bien que cher pour ce que c'est car il vaut le coup ! ce jeu parait tout c** mais asser drole et difficile (surtout au niveau de la camisole de force) si vous voulez avoir de la rage du fun et de la reflection sur comment passé le niveau je vous le conseil mais si vous voulez un gros jeu hyper long, magnifique et immersif je ne le conseil pas DU TOUT mais je conseil plutot un The Witcher lol

author: {'steamid': '76561198025079461', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1440636164}
review:
having played the original with little problems and not knowing of said problems (thank you based vista!), i was wondering why the heck there was a remastered version in my library. needless to say i'm not surprised windows 8 fucked up so much (personal reasons pertaining to a certain blocky crafting game)... but playing the remastered, unity based version does feel buttery smooth compared to the original flash game. i might have to drag a friend along too because it still is every bit as hilarious as the original, and it has multiplayer. why? because bugs that lead to developer hilarity mean they keep the bug in.

yes, multiplayer started out as a bug and became a feature. and when you go through the bosses again with those limited lives, you'll want 'em.

it's a funny game. and it has everything you need for a good platformer, namely, tight, responsive controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058033790', 'num_games_owned': 1234, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1440685214}

author: {'steamid': '76561198013093574', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 138, 'last_played': 1440520496}
review:
Simple gameplay? Check.
Cool art style? Check.
Replayable? Check.
Silly story? Check.
New graphics engine? Check.
Is it the cause of more weight? Check.
Breaking 4th wall? Check.
Less punishing in worst moments? Check.
More punishing in easy moments? Check.
Bugs fixed? Check.
Bugs made to be features? Check.
Steam Workshop? Check.

BUT WHAT THE HELL IS THIS GAME ABOUT?
NOONE TELLS YOU THAT! THERE IS NO TIME TO EXPLAIN!

author: {'steamid': '76561198059561891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 416, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1442215108}
review:
Why are you fighting a shark that shoots torpedoes? Why is there a mole with a drill coming out its mouth and ass? There is No Time To Explain, just have fun and roll with it! That is the mentality and utter joy of this title. From being in a candy land to inside your own body this game is constantly changing it's visual style, challenges, and even game play during certain segments. This on top of the randomness make for one hell of a physics based puzzle game. No area in the game over stays its welcome and the game is constantly pushing something new on you, rather that be a boss fight or shifting into a shoot em up side scroller. There is also little things that give No Time To Explain a cherry on top. The game features a level editor, local co-op, and secret collectible hats. The graphics have been over hauled and are hilariously done and look great. The soundtrack is fun to listen too and the voice work made me laugh many times. While I can't comment on comparing this to the original. The remastered version certainly seems to give you bang for your buck. With plenty of levels in the story mode and more through Steam Workshop support.
So save yourself the effort of going back in time and just buy the game now before it's too late, you won't regret it.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/M4OnD92n7E4
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

author: {'steamid': '76561198005648447', 'num_games_owned': 5290, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1437814362}
review:
[i]Il faut que je le prévienne ! Il doit savoir ! Où est ma montre temporelle ? Zut... Ah. Là. Voilà. Hop, je règle sur « 05/07/13 ». Je pense que je suis large, le jeu est sorti en 2011 puis début 2013 sur la plateforme de valve, et je pense l'avoir acquis pendant les soldes Steam d'été. Je me prépare mentalement à lui dire. Il doit savoir. JE dois savoir. Mon moi du passé doit être informé : le vrai « No Time To Explain », celui dont le développeur avait réellement l'intention de sortir, ne sortira que 2 ans plus tard …[/i]

[u]J'ai pas le temps de vous expliquer. Enfin si, un peu.[/u]

[url=http://www.newgrounds.com/portal/view/558562]« No Time To Explain » [/url], petit jeu flash d'une minute par les développeurs du plus récent « SpeedRunners », reçut un certain succès sur les sites de l'internet. Le projet d'un jeu complet fut alors kickstarté et réussi, puis atterrit en version commercialisée pour PC, Mac et Linux. Drôle, varié, addictif, une seule chose empêcha vraiment de savourer le titre correctement : le jeu avait été conçu avec un moteur flash et les problèmes de performance nuisirent la bonne expérience de jeu pour nombre de joueurs, même ceux possédant une bonne machine. L'alternative était de jouer en mode fenêtré, mais le problème – en plus de devoir tirer un trait sur une bonne lisibilité sur nos écrans de riches – était que la souris n'était pas bloquée par les bords de la fenêtre, obligeant un retour sur le bureau pour peu qu'on fût assez distrait. 
Fin juillet 2015, le jeu est supprimé du store sur Steam et remplacé par sa nouvelle version - oui j'ai un jeu collector, nananalalère - et ses propriétaires gagnent un jeu supplémentaire dans leur bibliothèque Steam : « No Time To Explain Remastered ».

[u]L'immaterium du fun[/u]

Le gameplay est simple : on utilise une sorte de lance-plasma qui peut s'activer en continu comme un réacteur. Initialement, la poussée, plus forte en approchant le sol, permet de décoller davantage, jusqu'à ce que l'élan procuré finisse par s'épuiser. Il faut donc doser ses « sauts » en gérant l'élan, l'angle de tir, le timing. Les niveaux offrent de chouettes parcours, et au fur et à mesure, de nouvelles mécaniques : bumpers, rotation de l'écran, possibilité de se transformer en torche humaine ou en fatboy rappelant les transformations de Wario dans les jeux de plateforme à son nom sur gameboy.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=487210524

La côté tricky aussi, c'est que l'arme offre un fort recul, si bien que l'on peut aller à sa perte dans les niveaux exigeants de détruire des obstacles avec l'arme ou encore lorsqu'on l'utilise offensivement contre les boss. Le jeu ne se suffit donc pas de son simple gimmick et chaque « monde » apporte sa spécialité : l'usage d'un shotgun surpuissant permet de se transformer en projectile humain dans un niveau, un autre où l'on projette le personnage comme si l'on utilisait un lance-pierre ou encore ces niveaux totalement différents dans l'approche (Runner, SHMUP, …). Les boss sont tout aussi funs à affronter et exigent une utilisation maîtrisée du lance-plasma. Enfin, je vous passe les cinématiques super drôles en début et fin de niveau, incitant à continuer pour avoir sa dose de « lolz » et de scènes absurdes et grotesques.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=486165257

[u]Riz-munster-aide[/u]

Qu'offre donc la version remastérisée ? Un jeu sous Unity, réglant les problèmes de performance et permettant de jouer en plein écran sans compromis, pas de glitchs en tous genres, la possibilité de jouer avec le pad 360 (intégration complète de la manette) ce qui est plutôt agréable, quelques options mineures comme la sensibilité souris ou le fait de la simuler avec les touches fléchées - bon j'ai pas trouvé ça vraiment jouable par contre. On a aussi la possibilité d'être rejoint par un autre joueur en local (un au clavier + souris, l'autre au pad). Enfin en matière de contenu, quelques emplacements de chapeaux (collectibles) dans les niveaux ont été remaniés et pour moi le changement le plus notable : les boss sont enfin plus agréables à affronter. Ici pas de « vous recommencez tout depuis le début si vous vous faites touchés une seule fois » mais la présence de 3 vies supplémentaires. C'est un peu moins frustrant mais le challenge est toujours là (si vous n'arrivez pas à doser un boss, vous allez de toute manière finir par perdre toutes vos vies). Et bien entendu, l'éditeur de niveaux et le workshop Steam sont toujours présents.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=486164831

[i]En clair[/i] : c'est la version qui aurait dû être commercialisée depuis le début. J'ai toutefois pris plaisir à reparcourir le jeu et à regarder encore une fois ces cinématiques débiles et hilarantes. Le jeu, bien que court, puisqu'il faut compter de 3 à 5 heures suivant le skill et la volonté de chercher  tous les collectibles du jeu, arrive à amuser de bout en bout. Alors bien sûr on peut compter davantage d'heures si l'on cherche le 100 %, si l'on se prête au speedrun, ou encore si l'on joue les niveaux créés par les utilisateurs, mais je ne suis pas convaincu que l'étiquette du prix actuelle (15€) soit tout à fait bien ajustée …

[i]Cette recommandation est aussi disponible sur [url=http://www.gamesidestory.com/2015/08/16/gametest-no-time-to-explain-remastered-pc/]GameSideStory[/url][/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197973914878', 'num_games_owned': 1089, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1439428815}
review:
TL;DR = Hell yes you should buy this game, you start out with a laser powerful enough to propel you around.

A LASER.  THAT MAKES YOU FLY.  I MEAN SERIOUSLY GUYS COME ON.

Now, the real review.

It ain't heavy on plot (or if it is, I haven't seen much of it), but that's okay - the bits that you do get give you enough "wait, WTF?!" moments to keep you eager to get moving.  They make you want to see what's over the next spike-studded hill.  And those hills *will* be spike-studded: this is something of a hardmode game in the vein of VVVVVV, Super Meat Boy, and the like, requiring both skillful control and a degree of planning in what you're going to do next.

It also ain't really combat heavy.  There are bosses, and the ones I've fought were fun and challenging, but aside from some detours from the standard play style it's mostly navigational challenges.

What it has in spades is STYLE.  Every stage presents something new you have to work around, and the interaction between your character and the stage just makes things that much more interesting (especially when you end up in a different pair of shoes - or hat).

So yes, I have had a blast with the time I've already spent with it - and I intend to spend more still learning what more it has to offer me.  I most strongly recommend picking it up; it has the feel of that rare sort of game that would cause one to brave the wilds of Newgrounds to find the diamond in the rough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083100143', 'num_games_owned': 1638, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 559, 'last_played': 1438062698}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043609914', 'num_games_owned': 3556, 'num_reviews': 834, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1445691314}
review:
I was thinking if I should write a brand new review or just add what is new in the remaster so here goes. Here is my original review for No Time To Explain http://steamcommunity.com/id/snortcannon/recommended/227280/ 

No Time To Explain is the remaster from the developers Tiny Build games. No Time To Explain is a puzzle physics platforming game where the main goal is to use a physics gun to launch yourself across levels. 

The original game was very fun but now we have a remaster but is it worth your money ?

For people who haven't bought it already it's must own and for people who own it, I'll run down the fixes.

The game now has a very solid frame rate which was  a big problem in the original game. It was a pain in the ass to fight some of the bosses and some of the levels were a complete nightmare with the unstable frame rate.

The graphics are fixed up and look a little high res than the graphics from the original game which looked like a very poor flash game.

They added a life system which makes the game a challenge which the original game lacked off. The original game was really easy and the challenge is a nice touch. 

But there are a few issues about this game too. The game is still kind of buggy. I found myself stuck on platforms and sometimes the gun wouldn't shoot, but overall it's not too bad.

No Time To Explain Remastered is a really good upgrade to a really fun game. For people who don't own it, this is a must pick up and for people who have this upgrade this is really worth another playthrough. The game is kind of difficult but this is still a very fun game. I give No Time To Explain Remastered a 8,5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197998985381', 'num_games_owned': 1678, 'num_reviews': 173, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1438479140}
review:
A decent remake of the previous Flash prototype. This game is a fun platformer with unique mechanics. And every now and then the mechanics change a little, while still keeping the same idea. And several jokes and over-the-top stuff (no spoilers here)!

Pros:
+ Graphics (smooth 60 fps! except on cutscenes)
+ Music
+ Gameplay
+ The several jokes spread through the game
+ Local co-op (requires gamepads)
+ Keyboard+Mouse and/or Gamepad controls
+ Steam Cloud and Steam Workshop

Cons:
- No in-game resolution setting. You must hold SHIFT while starting the game to change the resolution. But the game looks uglier in higher resolutions.
- The "beam" sound/noise can get annoying after a while.
- No way to skip to a single specific level. We can skip to a levelset, but not to a level inside the levelset.
- 1.2GB seems a bit too large. I believe the assets could have been better compressed/optimized.
- Restarting a level takes a bit too long. The screen slowly fades to black, and a couple of seconds later the level restarts.
- Cannot drop "guest" players without quitting.
- Cannot change between gampad and keyboard+mouse without quitting.

Misc:
± The jump is useless. But you are not supposed to use the jump, anyway.
± Collectible hats spread throughout the levels.

Yes, I recommend this game!

The "cons" are minor stuff (in my opinion), and are not deal-breakers.

Still unsure? Wanna try it before buying it? Look for the in-browser "No Time To Explain" Flash game, it works as a demo/prototype for this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069885435', 'num_games_owned': 542, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1580685625}
review:
Where the hell do I even begin?

Well, I remember playing the original only because I watched Game Grumps play it.

The original was okay, given that you can turn off the guy screaming all the time (which was very fucking annoying), and only cause I was lucky enough to play it on a pc that ran it perfect. But then I got a new computer (Which was better than the old one) and it runs even worse. I learned it the hard way that the original engine was absolute dogshit.

Anyway, they use a new engine now, and the game runs smoothly, which is great. However there are too many different physics and features that actually piss me off.

First things first,
[h1]The life system[/h1]

Now, I remember playing the original, and it's like any old platform indie game. Challenging levels, bosses here and there, and infinite lives. Now they apparently decided to add in a "finite" life mechanic where when you're on boss levels (or certain levels), you have a limited number of lives. That number would be 5 (or 6, I didn't count how many exactly). 5 lives would seem plentiful, but there's only one problem with this.
[b]The new physics ruins boss fights.[/b]
How, you may ask? Well, let's just say, now whenever you're standing still, and you start shooting, you slide. Doesn't sound like a big deal, but I had a lot of trouble on second boss (SECOND BOSS MIND YOU) because you have to shoot the shark, but, you have to avoid him, the pit below you, and the spikes. Plus the platforms they provide are extremely small, and you will fall to your death if you don't pay attention.

Next thing,
[h1]The new physics engine[/h1]

Yes, it's all fine and dandy that they got a new one. Certainly runs better than the original (as I stated before). However, my only problem is when you jump, it kills the momentum from your laser. Why? In the original, you were able to jump, and get even higher when you shot your laser when combining the jump and laser. however, now,  it gives you less height, and the only real way to get good momentum is if you do it frame perfect, or you just start shooting when you're standing on the ground.
Another problem I have with this, is the fact that in the original, when you shot the laser, you could see it shrinking, thus telling you that you are running out of laser power and you would need to touch the ground again to regain the momentum. In this game, there's no visual of that, therefore, if you relyed on it in the first, then yeah, have fun without the visual. It's only really frustrating because in the water levels, you would REALLY need the visual to be able to tell whether you can jump over a spiked wall or not.


Now, I have beaten the game before, mind you. However, I feel that this new engine is just frustrating with the little tweaks and changes that have occurred. Even though the changes are minor, it's still very frustrating. It can (and does) change the entire flow of the game. 

Oh, and another con with the new engine is with the football guy, you can't spam the shotgun when standing on the ground. It sends you flying and you have to wait before you can do it again. That was honestly fun to me. But this actually affects the game because in the level where you first play football guy, you have to use the shotgun to blast through the blocks in your way. In the original, you could keep shooting and keep moving forward. The new engine disagrees, and doesn't allow that. Thus taking more time to complete the level, and increasing your chances of death (fucking spikes).



[h1]tl;dr[/h1]
[list]
[*]Runs smoothly
[*]Life system on boss levels (and certain other levels) are annoying af.
[*]Life system consists of 5 lives or so
[*]New physics engine makes your character slide when shooting on ground (really annoying)
[*]Sliding on ground is horrible for Shark Boss fight.
[*]No more football guy shotgun spam (new engine sends you flying everytime you shoot)
[*]Jumping and shooting down doesn't help anymore.
[/list]

Long story short, the new engine has its ups and downs. Really annoying for boss fights, levels, pretty much the entire game, and life system really shouldn't be there either. It runs smoother, which is the only upside I see in this.

If you already have it, cool, but I really don't recommend wasting $15 to play this, unless you really want to.

review:
Спасибо за такую игру!!Нет времени объяснять,пусть твой пукан горит!Если сравнивать обычную Not Time To Explain и No Time To Explain Remastered,то безусловно,No Time To Explain Remastered лучше в тысячу раз!!Графика более доработанна!Теперь в эту игру может поиграть каждый!Её очень хорошо оптимизировали!!Битвы с боссами просто пуканопригорающие!!В обычной No Time To Explain ты мог появляться сколько угодно раз.В новой же версии у тебя есть всего 4 жизни,что довольно сильно делает эту игру хардкорной!

author: {'steamid': '76561198063686672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1438024798}
review:
No Time To Explain Remastered was my first full playthrough with this game and instead of chosing the mouse and keyboard I went straight to the controller which was a wise decision! The controls are far better with a stick and still very easy to learn. That's just a hint before I get to the actual review! ;)

No Time To Explain is a game about you! Yes you, from the future, back to the past to fight against giant crabs, sharks, mules and yourself from the eviiiiiiil future! Of course there are tons of level riddles and challenges which you have to take on your way to overcome your evil future! They are coming in a wide range from jumping and floating to the next portal over shooting or pulling yourself as a hardened football player or frog-clone.

But enough of that technical and gameplay stuff, what really makes the game playworthy is the story and the way it is progressing! I laughed until I cried tears of pure joy on my stream and my viewers enjoyed the game as well. I really recommend to play this game with a friend or on stream because it increases the fun!

There are some user generated levels and one special level added at the end of the game as a bonus which is incredible funny and challenging again, after you beat the story. Go and try your skill on these crazy tracks, too!

I clearly recommend you this timeless or timeful (?) game which will be a nice addition to your gaming library!

review: this is a massive step up from the original game.  The graphics are a lot better, it controls better than the original, it even sounds better than the original.  The one thing that this game does that I didn't like was giving you a limited number of lives on the boss fights.  I understand why they did it, and it definitely added a new element of skill and strategy to some extent.  But I liked it better when I didnt have to worry about dying over and over again.  It was better when all I had to do was shoot whatever boss the boss was and not have to worry about getting hit.  That said, it's still a very good game, and certainly a step up from the original.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079469604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1437514016}
review:
I'm really glad the devs fixed this game. There was a certain point in the original game you simply could not get through, no matter what you tried. Anyway, the concept is great. You blast yourself around levels with this giant laser gun pursuing your future self who is being maimed by a giant crab... and eventually other things. (No spoilers here! :P) At times you'll find the laser gun propulsion parkour a little challenging, but you'll get the hang of it. Then they'll throw some new game mechanic at you and throw you totally out of the loop. Despite that, the voice acting is pretty well done and all performed by just one guy, seriously, kudos to him for his voice acting. The voice acting kinda fits the feel of the story itself too, which is a little cheesy with the whole time travel aspect. Overall, this game is a really funny, semi-short game that I'd recommend to anyone looking for a few laughs and a good time. 

Oh yeah, and if you're still not sure about this game after reading this review, there's a flash version of the first few levels available. Just look it up, you'll find it somewhere, I'm sure. Thanks for reading and... OH CHRIST! MY RIBS! THEY'RE IN MY EYES! MY EYEEEEES!

author: {'steamid': '76561198034306697', 'num_games_owned': 1401, 'num_reviews': 617, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1437814251}
review:
[b]It's an incredibly short action platformer that relies on you controlling your character's flight and aerial movement with a future cannon gun weapon thing that was never explained. [/b]
The game gets tougher as you progress but respawning each time you die is relatively fast. It's kind of odd but depending on how you die you either respawn back on the last safe platform you were in or you reset the entire level you were in, which you can do optionally in the pause menu.
You go through a series of levels through different universes or dimensions or worlds or whatever with each worlduniversedimension often having different platforming themes with a few of them completely changing the gameplay regarding how you do your platforming for that specific unidimworld.

Personally I think it's mostly a vast improvement from the original on Steam.
[list]
[*]Now there's little to no lag of any kind thanks to its transition from Flash to the unpopular Unity engine.
[*]If you're in windowed mode, your mouse now stays within the game.
[*]The achievements aren't bugged anymore which actually make them a real challenge to acquire.
[*]The gameplay for the straitjacket and clone are changed to be easier to control after getting accustomed to.
[*]A lot of the silly hats have been relocated to be more difficult to acquire. Some become a real challenge to even get.
[*]You get 3 lives in boss fights so if you waste them all and die you'll have to restart the entire fight.
[*]For some reason jumping slows your cannon jumping now and you're better off relying on taking flight solely with the cannon when required.
[*]The range in where you can get hurt from spikes seem to be larger though I can't tell if it's the spikes' kill range is higher or if your guy's hitbox is.
[/list]

Good fun but I can't say I'd pay 15 bucks for something this small in content though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117565044', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1621788579}

author: {'steamid': '76561198010883491', 'num_games_owned': 1932, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1450265793}
review:
Безумный трэш-платформер, в котором высунутая из-за экрана лапа краба держит копию вас из параллельной реальности из будущего. Вы не успеваете ничего осмыслить, как выбегаете из своего дома с оставленным поздней копией лазером, и в спешке пытаетесь его освоить. Игра издевается, раз за разом реагируя на вашу неуклюжесть смешными репликами умирающей вместе с вами копии. А куски вас из будущего шмякающие об экран — это не то, к чему можно быстро привыкнуть! К тому же, если задуматься, как-то сразу настроение портится… Я — в будущем — мертв?!
[url=http://dokole.me/index.php/nemnogo-pro-no-time-to-explain-remastered/]Подробнее на dokole.me[/url]

review:
No Time To Explain is a fun game with humor and good gameplay. There are some levels that might make you feel frustrated at times. While chasing yourself and alternating realities and fighting strange creatures all together it can be overwhelming. Well lucky you can do it in style as you can collect different hats and wear them! author: {'steamid': '76561198154910289', 'num_games_owned': 282, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1527384945}
review:
这开发者终于听了意见改善了游戏帧率，现在全屏可以60fps玩耍了，再也不卡顿了还加入了多人模式以及支持了创意工坊自定义关卡，好评，可见开发者的用心。
下面来说说游戏
没有剧情可言，反正我是没看懂好像是未来的自己被抓走了，要去救之类的==
横板过关，没有教学，自己试试吧
开始时你只有一把激光枪帮助你跳跃，之后会有其他人物代替你继续过关同时获得新武器[spoiler]（ 因为原主角被撞死了）	[/spoiler]
游戏中有收集要素，不过一般比较难拿。
PS：游戏本身看上去简单但却和super meat boy 一样鬼畜
PPS：请打折购买，或等进包购买

author: {'steamid': '76561198036716666', 'num_games_owned': 569, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1458698070}
review:
[h1]GOT FOR FREE BECAUSE I OWNED THE ORIGINAL[/h1]

[b] Tested with a 360 controller and a mouse and keyboard [/b]

I 100 percented the original game, and gave it a poor review because... well the original was shit. The first "no time to explain" on steam suffered from some of the worst performance issues and some of the most backwards programming i have ever seen from a steam release, which was compounded more since it seemed to run on windows Aero and was only "compatable" with one version of windows (I believe i was using that version at the time and still suffered from god awful performance issues and glitches.)

[b]Pros[/b]:
+Comedy
+Gameplay has it's moments
+Less laggy and more responsive then the original (Framerate that doesn't make me suicidal)
+Changed from fullscreen to windowed and unlike the original it didn't crash my computer.
+Improved UI and menus
+Little to no glitches when compared with the original.
+The shotgun levels control great on controller / controller typically controls fine.
+Music is nice

[b]Cons[/b]:
-JUMPING KILLS MOMENTUM NOW... I can't even wrap my head around that concept in a platformer
-No option to turn off "screen shake" and other visual effects that in my opinion add nothing to the game.
-Only options to turn off sound FX and music, no option to turn off the future version of you's constant screaming.
-There is no constant gamefeel, i attempted to just jump, 2 tiles high onto a ledge over and over and found you can make the exact same jump, only 2/3 times
-Bad hitboxes
-Bad level design 
-The telekinesis levels are awful to control on a controller EDIT: And now on keyboard and mouse aswell.

[b]Jumping... gave me less momentum...[/b] 

[b]Odd[/b]:
~You can do a weird... "Double-momentum" jump or laser acceleration if you move towards a corner. In a tighter platformer i would be okay with this but in this game it only serves to make me sometimes overshoot my jumps.
~The original version had it so your laser would quickly go from shooting "very thick" to "very thin" so you could get a visual representation of momentum, i don't know if this was changed for performance reasons. 

[b]TL:DR[/b]: I would not recommend this game... It's 2 steps forward, 2 steps back although the original was atrocious to control it was at least exploitable, I could use the glitches in order to traverse faster. I'll use the comparison of sonic boom. This feels like sonic boom after they patched the "Knuckles infinite jump" By taking away the exploit you've taken the fun.

Still [b]TL:DR[/b]: The momentum in this game is awful.

EDIT: [b]One hundred percented the game, to prove i know what i'm talking about.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198049053988', 'num_games_owned': 222, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 261, 'last_played': 1539530488}
review:

So here it is:
[h1]PROS[/h1]
[list]
 [*]SMOOOOOTHLY gaming experience.
 [*]Funny story
 [*]Challanging levels
[/list]
[h1]CONS[/h1]
[list]
 [*]Not that suitable for a toaster.
 [*][b]NO QUICKSAVE[/b], you need to restart the whole chapter when you quit the game!!!! If you beat a level that cause raging before you quit, you need to do it AGAIN!!! I remember the old one has the feature, so... Maybe they removed it for a reason?
[/list]
Anyway, it's a good game. And hope you enjoy this 100% free 12.74$ thingy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013028710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 355, 'last_played': 1437436312}
review:
Literally unplayable.

As a big fan of the first game, with 70 hours played, I can say this remake is a significant downgrade from the original.

The controls and physics are way worse, and turn fun puzzle solving into levels where you are just fighting the controls.

It's clear that a portion of this comes from console style controls being nearly directly ported over to the pc version.

Extremely restrictive mouse movement, with insane inverse mouse acceleration makes me question if they even tested the game before they released it.

If you are looking to play this game then go pick up the original, seriously, it's a lot better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983548320', 'num_games_owned': 3595, 'num_reviews': 180, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1438929671}
review:
No Time to Explain is a comedic puzzle platformer that features ridiculous amounts of "rocket jumping". You have an extremely powerful and exaggerated laser, though sometimes the game will change it up with different weapons, such as an equally powerful and exaggerated shotgun. Rather than using these weapons to combat creeps, you'll be using them to traverse and solve the level.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KtE9ev0oXSg
The mechanics are simple and easily understood. You can move left and right, jump, aim, shoot, and do a little jig (there is a dance button. Why? Reasons). It's really just that simple. You'll be using the game's weapon that it provides to work out a solution to the end of the map, with the map and the game's physics itself as your adversaries. As mentioned before, there are no mobs to fight (at least from what I've played). The only combat that I've experienced so far, with almost 2 hours in, is the boss fights them selves. The puzzles are satisfying and the map designs are smart, but I do feel the game could of gained rather than detracted if it threw in a few combat scenarios. It feels almost like a waste, that the player can't use these impressive weapons in more meaningful ways, other than traversing. Luckily, the puzzle and platforming aspect is quite well done and serves well as the game's main dish.

The presentation is a little simplistic but it does the job. It goes with a flash cartoon look, something similar to say Castle Crashers, but the characters and animation has a charming appeal to it. The game's focus on comedy really helps out with it's overall feel and atmosphere. It's probably not the best looker of the year, but there's something really lovable about the characters and the animation.

Overall, No Time to Explain is an interesting take on the puzzle platform genre, with smart level design, charming animations, and ridiculous weaponry. I can safely say, I've enjoyed my time with the game.

Pros:
- Charming and comedic characters and animation
- The weapons feel very powerful
- Smart map design

Cons:
- Under utilizes the awesome weapons

author: {'steamid': '76561198067366334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1437400771}
review:
I'll start with the bad stuff. While this is certainly an upgrade to framerate, there are very few settings, none for resolution or control remapping. Thing of note: with max cursor speed I still struggle to rapidly make a 180 degree turn, which makes the game more difficult than it should be. Another issue would be the weird checkpoint system, but I assume that to be a feature.

The good stuff is the story and the gameplay, or at least as it would be without the controls issue. It is THE thing that kept me playing and struggling through the tough levels, so thanks to developer and writer for giving this game to me after I was disappointed by the previous unplayable one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961368637', 'num_games_owned': 1633, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1437193869}
review:
Disclaimer: I’ve been provided a key of this game for free.  My comments are my own.

No Time To Explain Remastered makes what the original was even better.

Gameplay Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7tNyVuXfKgo

No, the game doesn't run on Flash(Even though it does have it's uses for games that don't chew through all your CPU) but on Unity.  Yes, that Unity.  This means No Time To Explain is more compatible, more playable, and, possibly, has a lot less bugs, crashes, bad stuff.

I've only played this for a short bit and what I played I had fun with.  It's ridiculous, being able to fart while dancing.  Why do you have to save your future self when you have his neat gun?  And can I get more hats?

All in all, No Time to Explain is something that will catch someone's eye and they'll have lots of fun playing it.

review:
"Я-это ты из будущего,нет времени объяснять"
Для тех кто играл в оригинал,особо нового не будет.
А для новичков расскажу.
No Time To Explain-это платформер по типу Meat Boy в котором нужно преодолеть препятствия.
А поможет в этом не лёгком деле Пушка из Будущего.
Юмор здесь...Так скажем на любителя.
Игра длится несколько часов(в зависимости от скила или игры с друзьями).
Итог:это красивая и доработанная версия оригинала.

review:
So...an remaster of an flash game in Unity, which is much better, because original was capped at 30 FPS and had serious lag issues to the point where not everyone was happy about this game.
After this remaster, everything bad was changed to good: The FPS is pretty much uncapped, gameplay is smoother, boss fights are better and have lives, bugs and glitches that was present in flash version got fixed and still, humor is outrageous.
An worthy one compared to original.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123288775', 'num_games_owned': 3061, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1482557201}
review:
非常值得一玩的游戏，剧情比较荒诞。就像商店页面介绍的那样，"I Am You From The Future! No Time To Explain, Follow m-OH CHRIST!"。玩家依靠一种喷射器来通过各种地形，类似于食肉男孩那种类型，个人感觉操作难度中等偏上，比较棘手的关卡死几次就能找到手感。既不会简单到无聊，也不会让人卡半个多小时一直过不了关。
这个游戏是开发商tinyBuild在steam上的第一款游戏，代表作是speedrunners，开发商重置了这部作品并给原版拥有者免费提供一份重制版，还是诚意十足的。
原版游戏进过包（indiegala "doorways bundle"/bundle stars "reboot 9.0"），不知道现在激活还送不送重制版

author: {'steamid': '76561197979724838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 376, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1437171710}
review:
I'm going to lead with the strong points: It's funny as hell if you like absurdist humour. The presentation is good, the animated assets are pretty simplistic but fluid, music is pretty great, it's a novel concept, and there are times when I had fun with it. But despite all the blood, sweat and tears that have gone into making a more functional release of the game, it turns out that even functioning (mostly) as intended, the design of the game makes for kind of a crapshoot experience.

In a nutshell, the crippling blows are inconsistency and frustration factor. Jetting around on that laser pulse is not an accurate science, and the hitboxes of spikes and other hazards are extremely unforgiving. When you die, you will typically reappear on the last patch of solid ground you stood on, but the detection for this is picky sometimes, the laws of mechanics change from level to level, and some levels require you to make a series of ridiculously precise jumps and hovers before touching down, making for some insane difficulty spikes. On certain levels or when dying to certain hazards, death will restart the level entirely. Sometimes level elements STILL don't behave as intended, particularly in the candy world. Level design as a whole often feels redundant and amateur, making you do the same sorts of jumps with different mechanics and layouts, rather than exploring more varied ways of using the existing mechanics like the laser-bending bolts.

Besides the laser, there are levels that give you similar but varied means of propulsion, some of which are more fun than the laser but you see very little of, others which are interesting in theory but due to their implementation are just a further frustration in control factor.

The Remastered edition has done this much: it stabilized the game, and retooled the boss levels and chase sequences to give you 3 spare lives, rather than switching back and forth between "infinite lives" and "no lives" on a case-by-case basis. It also added several new lines for the characters, which unfortunately stand out rather blatantly and don't sound as good, but whatever. I was, finally, able to complete the game rather than throw up my arms somewhere around the halfway point after falling through the level and breaking the scripting for the Nth time. I would even say it's maybe worth picking up at the $3-$5 level if you have a high tolerance for frustration factor.

Personally, I'm just glad to be done with it, able to watch the ending, and not have it lurking in my half-completed games list forevermore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005120097', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1437130252}
review:
[h1]FULL VIDEO REVIEW[/h1] http://youtu.be/ZuDrgOFUkgs
[h1]PROS[/h1]
[b]++Crazy story that keeps you guessing what will come next, and what actually shows up is even more bizzare[/b]
+Laser flying mechanic is fun and unique
+New abilities keep the game fresh throughout
+Great soundtrack
+Steam workshop maps and ingame editor for custom levels

[h1]CONS[/h1]
[b]--Base game is very short less than 3 hours if you are competent at platformers[/b]
-Some QoL issues involving the laser
-Level select doesn’t allow you to choose exact levels, only worlds
-Multiplayer is local only

	No Time to Explain Remastered is a great little platformer with a lot of content packed in. Your mission is to blast your way through alternate universes using your laser beam device that enables you to fly using the momentum and force of the blast. While the story mode is only about 2-3 hours long, it is a story so insane, so crazy that you will be constantly trying to guess what comes next, only to be very very wrong. Throw in a level editor with steam workshop support and some multiplayer and you have a game with a decent chunk of fun to be had.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970365871', 'num_games_owned': 694, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1437136063}
review:
An absolute little blast. It starts off with a bang and throws you head first into your time travelling alternate dimension journey.

It starts of silly, and gets crazier as time goes on. I think this is a real little gem of a game, although it could do with being priced a little lower.

Your basic weapon is a giant laser like beam weapon you both use to fight the giant beast attacking your future self, and to propel yourself around the map and obstacles. The mechanics are simple, propel yourself around spikes, traps and and platforms to catch up to your currently being mutilated future self and save him. It's not easy though, it's really not easy; but the music, sense of urgency, and cries from your future self are hilarious and blood pumping.

Did I mention there are hats? Yes, you can collect hats through the zones, and secret little areas and become all the fashionable rage as you travel through space and time battling space crabs and saving yourself. You can also press spacebar and do a little jiggle dance. For extra awesomeness get the funkiest hat, and jiggle and laser your way through dimensions.

After finishing a set of areas and a boss battle, you get to the starting area with floating orbs. Blow these up and you have a portal to yet another dimension, with new enemies and yet another self that needs saving as they're being mauled.

It really is a fun little game, it might not look like it has a story but it does. As convoluted and confusing it might appear as you play at first. Things do make a bit more sense as you progress.

It's darn fun, the looks well and plays well. If it has a leaderboard I'd probably always be at the bottom, but hell it's fun.

Biggest issue is the price, it's a good game. Is it worth €14,99 though? That's hard to say.

PC Gameplay

[url]http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OqRwTE2IN9Q[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970364632', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1514249378}
review:
JUST WATCH THE TRAILER! THERE'S NO TIME TO EXPLAIN!

On a more serious note, though:
The technical issues of the original Flash version are a thing of the past. This is the same game, from the future! It was completely redone using the Unity engine, so it should run smoothly on all systems now.

Oh, you don't know the original? A hilarious platformer, quite brutal, and quite hard. Sometimes it can be a bit frustrating, but this is mostly alleviated by the hilarity of it all. If you like the trailer, you'll probably like the game as well.
